review_title: A Haven for the Privileged: Protecting the Elite's Interests
job_title: Senior Research Fellow in London, England
pros: If you were born white and privileged, or don't mind scratching their backs for meager rewards, this institution is your ticket to preserving the status quo. A perfect paradise for the upper and upper-middle classes, where royal institutions and their allies in Parliament thrive. Brace yourself for a system that champions the elite while leaving the rest to pick up the crumbs.
cons: Prepare to be thoroughly disgusted if you believe this institute is genuinely committed to its mission. Brace yourself for a workplace that will leave you tremendously disappointed if you yearn for fairness, inclusivity, or policy innovation. It's a bitter pill to swallow, witnessing the stark reality of a hollow institution that falls far short of its purported values.

pros: We used to have free lunch in the canteen every day which was a great perk given the office’s central location
cons: - I happened to have a poor middle manager, I’d label this person as an ‘absentee manager’ which was extremely frustrating. Even though I was this person’s first direct report and had issues, no one ever was curious about my feedback - Management in general is very poor across the board even if for various reasons - The other senior leaders in my team were also completely disinterested in my career progression or goals, despite me always getting great feedback from colleagues in other departments - At the same time many of my colleagues were experiencing the other type of bad management, managers who’d overpower and manipulate people while aggrandizing themselves, they’d rant and demand unreasonable things and use too much of junior staff’s time for inappropriate tasks like booking their personal flights and so on, and junior people would work longer hours even though their career progression over the years would be miniscule - The pay is extremely low, even for this industry, and any adjustments are small too - Very qualified and highly educated junior staff are hired, but very little investment in their progress is made, seems like a waste

pros: Great events, the right people are awesome, opportunity to attend all events including research events so if you're studying you get some fantastic insight. Building in beautiful part of London and flexible working available (depending on department, but most people worked hybrid). Some staff very supportive. Chance to meet influential people in a historical building. Library on the first floor you can work from. Good quality Dell laptops (not the thinkpads every other work gives you).
cons:
Work/life balance in poor. Even in a junior position, I was called on multiple Saturdays and asked to work. Senior staff can have big egos and are not afraid to shout at you. Harsh work environment. A bit toxic, i.e. staff often say bad things about each other. I particularly remember this when I was new. I would be introduced to a colleague and immediately told about their bad qualities.

Staff work incredibly hard and tend to snap. Feels very personal. Good place to work but you need thick skin. Researchers do not respect senior staff.

pros: Location Prestige Location Location Location

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in London, England
pros: Incredibly stimulating environment, chance to meet really interesting people, autonomy to develop ideas and writing on important policy issues.
cons: Managers had huge discretion over how to manage - so management styles varied massively, from absentee manager to micromanager. This was also an environment in which some bullying and discrimination was possible because managers themselves weren’t really scrutinised for how they managed - only for fundraising success.

pros:
Chatham House is a historic and prestigious institute, colleagues are all intelligent, passionate and driven people, we work in small focused research teams, have excellent networking opportunities and exposure to high-level people/forums as a member of staff.

Great London office, includes canteen with free lunch, library and access to all events (in non-pandemic times). Flexible working opportunities too.

Depending on role/programme/area of focus there are also opportunities to travel and work with international partners.
cons: Think tank salaries are not as competitive as the civil service or private sector (obviously), but this is not unique to Chatham House.
